results.description: The GraphQL error response discloses internal schema information (a type name and field name: 'documentaryUnits'). Although this is not a full __schema introspection dump, returning validation errors that reveal type/field names effectively exposes parts of the API schema to unauthenticated users. This schema leakage can help an attacker enumerate types and craft further queries or attacks. Recommend masking detailed error messages in production, disabling or restricting GraphQL introspection endpoints, enabling query whitelisting or persisted queries, and enforcing strict error handling/logging so schema details are not returned to clients.

results.description: The GraphQL error message leaks schema-related metadata: it names a field (topLevelDocumentaryUnits) and an argument ('input'). While this is not a full __schema introspection response, returning validation errors that reveal field and argument names is a form of schema disclosure/introspection. This information aids an attacker in mapping the GraphQL API and crafting further queries. Impact is limited (no sensitive data shown), so severity is LOW. Recommended mitigations: suppress detailed GraphQL validation errors in production, sanitize error messages, and consider restricting or disabling GraphQL introspection endpoints for unauthenticated clients.

results.description: The GraphQL endpoint returns detailed validation errors that disclose internal schema information (type name 'documentaryUnits', field names, and the top-level field 'topLevelDocumentaryUnits'). This is effectively an unintended form of introspection because an attacker can learn type and field names without using the official introspection query. While no sensitive data or query results are exposed, leaking schema details can assist attackers in crafting targeted queries or discovering other vulnerabilities. Recommend suppressing or genericizing error messages in production and disabling detailed schema leaks (or restricting introspection) to reduce information disclosure risk.

errors.message: Validation error (FieldUndefined@[topLevelDocumentaryUnits/items/identifer]) : Field 'identifer' in type 'DocumentaryUnit' is undefined
Validation error (FieldUndefined@[topLevelDocumentaryUnits/items/typ]) : Field 'typ' in type 'DocumentaryUnit' is undefined

results.description: The GraphQL response returns detailed validation errors that include the GraphQL type name (DocumentaryUnit) and the exact field paths that were queried (topLevelDocumentaryUnits/items/identifer and .../typ). This leaks schema information and reveals which fields are not defined, enabling an attacker to enumerate or probe the schema (field names/types/paths). While this is not an injection or execution vulnerability by itself, it is an information disclosure / field-suggestion style issue that can materially assist further attacks. Recommended mitigations: suppress or genericize validation error messages in production, remove detailed schema info from error payloads, implement stricter error handling, and consider limiting introspection or applying rate limits and auth checks on schema-discovery attempts.

This leaks schema information and reveals which fields are not defined, enabling an attacker to enumerate or probe the schema (field names/types/paths). Recommended mitigations: suppress or genericize validation error messages in production, remove detailed schema info from error payloads, implement stricter error handling, and consider limiting introspection or applying rate limits and auth checks on schema-discovery attempts.
